case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh and others v. Lakshmi Ice Factory and others

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 51 and 52/61 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 51 and 52/61 Appeals from the judgment and decree dated September 23, 1959, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree dated September 23, 1959 of Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in C. M. Applications Nos. 15 O.J. and 16 O.J. of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated September 23, 1959, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in C. M. Applications Nos. 15  O.J.  and 16

facts.text: Appellants are State of Uttar Pradesh and some of its officers.

anchor.surface_text: The, appellants in each case are the State of Uttar Pradesh, for short called U. P. and some of its officers and the respondents in one appeal are Lakshmi Ice Factory

facts.text: Respondents in one appeal are Lakshmi Ice Factory and certain of its workers.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondents in one appeal are Lakshmi Ice Factory and certain of its workers and in the other the Prakash Ice Factory and certain of its workers.

facts.text: Respondents in other appeal are Prakash Ice Factory and certain of its workers.

anchor.surface_text: and in the other the Prakash Ice Factory and certain of its workers. These appeals involve a question of construction of certain provisions of the U. P. Industrial

facts.text: Government of U. P. issued Notification on February 10, 1956 referring disputes between each Ice Factory and its workmen to Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: By a Notification issued on February 10, 1956, the Government of U. P. referred certain disputes which had cropped up between each of the Ice Factories and its respective

facts.text: Tribunal heard the matters but failed to pronounce its award in open court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal heard the matters but failed to pronounce its award in open court. Instead, on November 8, 1956, the Registrar of the Tribunal informed the Ice Factories

facts.text: On November 8, 1956, Registrar of Tribunal informed Ice Factories that award submitted to Government.

anchor.surface_text: Instead, on November 8, 1956, the Registrar of the Tribunal informed the Ice Factories that the award of the Tribunal had been submitted to the Government.

facts.text: Award published in U. P. Gazette on December 15, 1956, dated November 8, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On December, 15, 1956, the award was published in the U. P. Gazette and it appeared from this publication that the award was dated November 8, 1956.

facts.text: On December 26, 1956, Regional Conciliation Officer called upon Ice Factories to implement award immediately.

anchor.surface_text: On December 26, 1956, the Regional Conciliation Offi- cer appointed under the Act called upon the Ice Factories to implement the award immediately.

facts.text: Ice Factories moved Allahabad High Court on January 3, 1957 under Art. 226 for writs quashing award and prohibiting implementation.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Ice Factories moved the High Court at Allahabad on January 3, 1957 under Art. 226 of the Constitution for writs quashing the award and prohibiting

facts.text: Ice Factories contended award was nullity as not pronounced in open court.

anchor.surface_text: They contended that the award sought to be enforced was a nullity as it had not been pronounced in open court as required by certain rules to which reference

facts.text: High Court on September 23, 1959 allowed petitions and issued writs quashing Notification publishing award.

anchor.surface_text: By a judgment passed on September 23, 1959, the High Court allowed the petitions of the Ice Factories and issued writs quashing the Notification publishing

facts.text: Government issued Statutory Order dated July 14, 1954 under Section 3 of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Under this power the Government had issued an Order dated July 14, 1954 and this Order is hereafter called the Statutory Order.

facts.text: Government set up Tribunal under Clause 8 of Statutory Order.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of powers conferred by cl. 8 of the Statutory Order the Government had set up the Tribunal.

facts.text: Clause 9(7) of Statutory Order requires decision in writing, pronounced in open court, dated and signed at time of pronouncing.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clause  7  of this clause is in these terms The decision of the Tribunal shall be in writing and shall be pronounced in open court and dated and signed

facts.text: Tribunal framed Standing Order No. 36 requiring judgment pronounced in open court.

anchor.surface_text: Under this sub-clause the Tribunal framed certain Standing Orders. Standing Order No. 36 provided. Judgment shall be pronounced in open court either immediately

facts.text: On September 25, 1956, Tribunal informed parties that date for pronouncing award changed to October 9, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: but on September 25, 1956, the Tribunal informed the parties that the date for pronouncing the award had been changed to October 9, 1956.

facts.text: On October 9, 1956, award was not pronounced in open court, no intimation of other date given.

anchor.surface_text: On that date, however, the award was not pronounced in open court, not was any intimation of any other date for its pronouncement given to the parties.

facts.text: Award had never been pronounced in open court.

anchor.surface_text: The award had in fact never been pronounced in open court.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Sarkar, J. on February 7, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.- These two appeals have been heard together.

facts.text: High Court held provisions of cl.9(7) imperative and quashed award.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that they were and thereupon quashed the Notification publishing the award. The appellants contend that the High Court was in error

facts.text: Appellants contend provisions are directory, failure to pronounce does not void award.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that the High Court was in error and that the provisions are only directory and that the failure of the Tribunal to pronounce

facts.text: Ice Factories contend provisions imperative.

anchor.surface_text: The Ice Factories contend for the contrary view.
under Art. 226 of the Constitution for writs quashing the award and prohibiting the Government and the workmen from taking steps to implement it.
Section 3 of the Act gives the Government power in certain circumstances to make provisions by general, or special order  1  for appointing Industrial courts,  2  for referring any industrial dispute

concepts.interpretation: Gives power to Government to make general or special order providing for referring disputes for adjudication and incidental/supplementary matters including procedure.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: for adjudication in the manner provided in the order and  3  for matters incidental or supplementary to the other provisions of the order. Under this

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to make orders for industrial courts, reference of disputes, and incidental matters.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the U. P. Act provides as follows -- When an authority to which an industrial dispute has been referred for adjudication has completed it, enquiry, it shall, within such time as may be ,specified, submit its award to the State Government.

concepts.interpretation: Requires submission of award to Government after enquiry; does not specify manner of making award, which is covered by orders under S.3; contemplates making of award before submission.
concepts.unlisted_description: Submission of award to Government and enforcement.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clause  7  of this clause is in these terms The decision of the Tribunal shall be in writing and shall be pronounced in open court and dated and signed by the member or members of the Tribunal, as the case may be, at the time of pronouncing it.

concepts.interpretation: Imperative/mandatory requirement; failure to pronounce in open court renders award a nullity; essential for knowing date of decision for time limits, appeals, corrections.

concepts.unlisted_description: Decision to be in writing, pronounced in open court, dated and signed at pronouncement.

anchor.surface_text: Standing Order No. 36 provided. Judgment shall be pronounced in open court either immediately after the close of the arguments or on a subsequent date of which previous notice shall be given to the parties.

concepts.interpretation: Substantially same as Cl.9(7); to be interpreted similarly as imperative.
concepts.unlisted_description: Pronouncement of judgment in open court with notice.

anchor.surface_text: cl. 18 of the Statutory Order is in these terms The Tribunal or the adjudicator shall hear the dispute and give its or his decision within 180 days  excluding holidays but Dot annual vacations observed by courts subordinate to the High Court  from the date of reference

concepts.interpretation: Mandatory time limit for giving decision; 'giving decision' means pronouncing in open court as per Cl.9(7); award beyond time is nullity.

concepts.interpretation: Correction of errors within one month of 'giving' decision; requires known date from open court pronouncement.

concepts.unlisted_description: Correction of clerical/arithmetic errors within one month.

anchor.surface_text: cl. 31 of the Statutory Order. That clause is in these terms Except as provided in this Order and in the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, every order made or direction issued under the provisions of this Order shall be final and conclusive

concepts.interpretation: Finality subject to appeal under 1950 Act; requires known date of making award for appeal time limit.
concepts.unlisted_description: Finality of orders subject to appellate Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 7 of the Act of 1950, an appeal shall lie to the Appellate Tribunal from any award or decision of an Industrial Tribunal concerning certain specified matters.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for appeals from certain tribunal awards.

concepts.unlisted_description: Appeals to Appellate Tribunal from specified awards.

concepts.interpretation: Appeal time limit 30 days from publication or making of award; requires known date from pronouncement.

anchor.surface_text: an Industrial Tribunal mentioned in s. 7 includes a Tribunal set up under a State law which law does not provide for an appeal see s. 2 o  iii  of the Act of 1950.

concepts.interpretation: Definition includes state tribunals without appeal provision.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Aggarwala for the appellants referred us to the rule of construction stated in Maxwell on Interpretation of Statutes, 10th ed. at p. 381, which is as follows ,Where the prescriptions of a statute relate to the performance of a public duty and where the invalidation of acts done in neglect of them, would work serious general inconvenience or injustice to persons who have no control over those entrusted with the duty without promoting the essential aims of the Legislature, such prescriptions seem to be generally understood as mere instructions

concepts.interpretation: Not applicable here as no injustice/hardship, promotes legislative object; procedural rules usually imperative; Cl.9(7) imperative to effectuate time limits, appeals, corrections.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: he Statutory Order to be imperative,. A view that the provision was imperative would cause numberserious hardship to any one. The Government can alway

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule of statutory interpretation distinguishing imperative from directory provisions (Maxwell).

anchor.surface_text: It is also an accepted rule of construction that enactments regulating the procedure in courts are usually imperative Maxwell on Interpretation of statues 10th ed. p. 379.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to Cl.9(7) as regulating tribunal procedure.

anchor.surface_text: In the view that we have taken it is unnecessary to deal separately with Standing Order No. 36. The provisions of that Standing Order and cl. 9 7 of the Statutory Order

holdings.text: The provisions in sub-clause 7 of clause 9 of the Statutory Order are imperative and mandatory; failure to pronounce the award in open court renders it a nullity.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Maxwell directory rule inapplicable (no injustice); procedural rules imperative; purposive reading defeats object if directory; harmonious with cls.18 (time limit), 24(2) (corrections), 31 (finality/appeals), ss.6,7,10 Appellate Act requiring known pronouncement date.

holdings.text: The provisions of Standing Order No. 36 are substantially the same as clause 9(7) of the Statutory Order and must be interpreted in the same way as imperative.

anchor.surface_text: In the view that we have taken it is unnecessary to deal separately with Standing Order No. 36. The provisions of that Standing Order and cl. 9 7 of the Statutory Order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantially identical language to cl.9(7); cannot override Statutory Order; follows same interpretation as imperative.

holdings.text: Clause 9(7) of the Statutory Order and Standing Order No. 36 are not ultra vires the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.6 contemplates making award before submission but silent on manner; S.3(g) empowers supplementary procedure rules; no conflict or prohibition in S.6.

holdings.text: The award of the Tribunal is a nullity as it was never pronounced in open court.

anchor.surface_text: The award had in fact never been pronounced in open court. The first question is whether the provisions in sub el.  7  of el. 9 are imperative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factually never pronounced (f19,f20); applies imperative rule of cl.9(7).

precedents.citation: Montreal Street Railway Co. v. Normandin 1 1917 A. C. 170

anchor.surface_text: Montreal Street Railway Co. v. Normandin 1 which is cited in Maxwells book. That was a case in which certain Statutory provisions as to how the jury list was to be revised had number been followed and the question arose whether the verdict of a jury empannelled out of a list revised in disregard of the provision was a nullity. It was hold that the verdict was number a nullity as the provision regarding the revision of the jury list was merely directory.

precedents.case_name: Montreal Street Railway Co. v. Normandin
precedents.cited_proposition: Statutory provisions relating to performance of public duty are directory rather than imperative where invalidation would work serious general inconvenience or injustice without promoting essential legislative aims; jury list revision provisions are directory.
precedents.cited_holding: Verdict of jury empanelled from list revised disregarding statutory provisions is not a nullity.
